content: The "Adoption Equality Act of 1998" promotes the adoption of children with special needs. The "Adoption Equality Act of 1998" promotes the adoption of children with special needs by outlining requirements for children in care of child care agencies or foster families before adoption proceedings. The Adoption Equality Act of 1998 outlines requirements for children with special needs in care of child care agencies or foster families before adoption proceedings. A child who is not a citizen or resident of the United States and meets certain criteria shall be treated as meeting the requirements for adoption assistance payments. The Adoption Equality Act of 1998 specifies that children with special needs in care of child care agencies or foster families must meet certain criteria for adoption assistance payments. An exception states that no payment may be made to parents for a child who is not a citizen or resident of the United States and meets specific conditions. The Adoption Equality Act of 1998 outlines criteria for adoption assistance payments for children with special needs in care. It specifies that payments cannot be made for a child who is not a U.S. citizen or resident and was adopted outside the U.S. or brought into the U.S. for adoption purposes. Additionally, states must use any savings resulting from these criteria on child welfare services. The Adoption Equality Act of 1998, effective October 1, 1998, allows for the provision of services to children or families under this part or part B, including post-adoption services. SEC. 3.
